title: French Labor Overhaul Led by Unusual Figure: A Business Executive
abstract: Muriel Pénicaud has one of the toughest jobs around: overseeing a revamp of France’s voluminous labor code.

title: Tesla Directors Do Damage Control After Elon Musk Tweets
abstract: Tesla’s board of directors has hired multiple outside law firms, and a number of board members and Tesla employees have urged Mr. Musk to stop posting on Twitter.

title: Turkish President Calls for Boycott of U.S. Electronics Including the iPhone
abstract: The remarks by President Recep Tayyip Erdogan come as the country grapples with a worsening economic crisis and a widening diplomatic dispute with the United States.

title: How a Fake Group on Facebook Created Real Protests
abstract: The Black Elevation page held rallies, posted videos and encouraged the fight against racism. Whoever ran it even interviewed a job applicant.

title: Need a Quick Inspection of a 58-Story Tower? Send a Drone
abstract: With their low cost and ease of handling, drones are saving money and time on big construction projects. They could also save lives.

title: Trump’s Trade War Is Rattling China’s Leaders
abstract: While President Xi Jinping remains firmly in charge, friction with the Trump administration and troubles at home have dented his political dominance.

title: $100 Million Was Once Big Money for a Start-Up. Now, It’s Common.
abstract: Known as a mega-round in Silicon Valley, large-scale fund raising is producing a frenzy around tech companies with enough reach and momentum to absorb a large check.

title: The New York Times Joins Effort to Combat Trump’s Anti-Press Rhetoric
abstract: An initiative started by The Boston Globe has enlisted more than 200 newspapers nationwide to publish editorials on Thursday in favor of the news media.

title: Uber Picks N.S.A. Veteran to Fix Troubled Security Team
abstract: Matt Olsen, the former general counselof the National Security Agency, will replace Joe Sullivan, who was fired after the disclosure of a data breach.

title: Elon Musk’s Effort to Take Tesla Private to Get Board Oversight
abstract: Three independent members of the board will have “full power and authority” to evaluate any privatization efforts proposed by Elon Musk, the chief executive.

title: In New Zealand, Avocado Shortage Leads to Orchard Crime Wave
abstract: With prices for the fruit soaring after two years of low harvests, growers are experiencing a raft of thefts and black markets have sprung up to distribute the spoils.

title: Banks and Retailers Are Tracking How You Type, Swipe and Tap
abstract: Biometrics are moving way beyond fingerprints: To fight fraud, companies are building databases on people’s behaviors and movements.

title: Wall St. Rises on Earnings Optimism, Lira Rebound
abstract: Wall Street's three major indexes rose on Tuesday with the S&P 500 posting its strongest gain in three weeks as a string of healthy earnings boosted investor optimism and a rebound in the Turkish lira eased contagion fears.

title: A Chocolate Camp for Pastry Chefs
abstract: In a Las Vegas strip mall, a master chocolatier is teaching cooks from all over the world how to create the perfect bonbon.

title: DealBook Briefing: Elon Musk Has Answers. We Still Have Questions.
abstract: Tesla’s C.E.O. revealed more details about his plan to take the company private. They do little to clear up confusion surrounding the potential deal.

title: Elon Musk’s Tweets on Tesla Started a Tizzy. Someone Should Hit the Brakes.
abstract: Executives are permitted to disclose market-moving information on social media. But Mr. Musk has provided regulators ample opportunity to re-examine the policy.

title: Foxconn Is Feeling the Sag in Smartphone Sales. Apple? Not So Much.
abstract: The world’s biggest contract electronics manufacturer has recorded two straight quarters of declining profits, as smartphone sales stagnate.

title: This Company Keeps Lies About Sandy Hook on the Web
abstract: The father of a victim of the Sandy Hook shooting has tried to erase lies about his son from the internet, but Automattic, which runs WordPress.com, says “untrue content is not banned.”

title: VF Corporation Plans to Spin Out Its Denim Brands
abstract: The clothing company said that it will put its jeans lines, including Wrangler and Lee, into a separate business as their growth has slowed.

title: Why Turkey’s Lira Crisis Matters Outside Turkey
abstract: In past decades, plunges in emerging-market currencies have ignited broader crises. Turkey’s lira is crashing, and that has financial markets on edge.

title: Fierce and Unpredictable: How Wildfires Became Infernos
abstract: A division of the U.S. Forest Service is studying fire behavior as the blazes in the West become hotter and spread faster than ever before.

title: Those Long Security Lines at Airports? They May Move Quicker Soon
abstract: The T.S.A. is testing machines that can more thoroughly scan what’s in carry-on bags, so there would be less need to search bags by hand.

title: When the Menu Says ‘Organic,’ but Not All the Food Is
abstract: The term doesn’t mean much in restaurants, which are not required to undergo the same rigorous certifying process as farms and food companies.

title: Clues to Your Health Are Hidden at 6.6 Million Spots in Your DNA
abstract: With a sophisticated new algorithm, scientists have found a way to forecast an individual’s risks for five deadly diseases.

title: They Thought Hemophilia Was a ‘Lifelong Thing.’ They May Be Wrong.
abstract: Experimental gene therapies have yielded promising results in early trials. But the drugs have left some patients wary, worried that success will not last.

title: Tesla Board Surprised by Elon Musk’s Tweet on Taking Carmaker Private
abstract: The chief executive is said to have written his Twitter post last week in haste. But he said Monday he had Saudi financial backing for a buyout plan.

title: DealBook Briefing: Turkey’s Chaos Could Be Your Problem
abstract: The Turkish lira continues to slide, and that’s starting to affect markets and currencies around the world.

title: Plunge in Lira, Turkey’s Currency, Fuels Fears of Financial Contagion
abstract: The country’s economic crisis has been caused by soaring inflation, economic mismanagement by the Turkish government and tensions with the United States.

title: Turkish Regulators Step In to Deal With Fall in Lira
abstract: Turkish banks’ ability to swap liras for foreign currencies was curbed. The lira has been dropping since President Trump said he would raise tariffs on Turkish imports.

title: Richard Russell Stole a Plane in Seattle and Crashed It. How’d He Learn to Fly?
abstract: Flight instructors and aviation experts were split on whether video games and simulations could prepare someone to operate a real plane.

title: As Barnes & Noble Struggles to Find Footing, Founder Takes Heat
abstract: Sales are falling and critics say the company lacks a direction, sometimes seeming to give priority to sales of gifts and tchotchkes over books.

title: July Retail Sales Released, and Walmart Reports Earnings
abstract: A housing report may show weakness in the real estate market, and investors will be looking at the strength of Walmart’s online efforts.

title: China Seeks Influence in Europe, One Business Deal at a Time
abstract: A mysterious Chinese company went on a buying binge in the Czech Republic following Xi Jinping’s call for greater sway in the region. What was the cost?

title: A Gas Pipeline to Italy? Five Star Backers Sense a Betrayal
abstract: The populist party came to power after a campaign filled with conspiratorial overtones against globalist forces. Now it faces one of its first tests of real-life governing.

title: Russia and 4 Other Nations Settle Decades-long Dispute Over Caspian Sea
abstract: The five states with shorelines on the Caspian Sea agreed on a formula to divide up the world’s largest inland body of water, potentially clearing the way for oil and gas development.

title: Amid Kremlin Victories, Putin Fails to Persuade West on Russian Sanctions
abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin has nimbly exploited differences between Washington and its allies, but he has yet to translate that into fewer sanctions against Russia.

title: Richard Russell, Who Stole Plane Near Seattle, Raises Troubling Security Questions
abstract: Richard B. Russell, a ground service agent at Seattle-Tacoma International Airport, flew a turboprop aircraft for nearly an hour over Puget Sound.

title: A Congressman, a Financial Deal and an Intricate Web of Conflicts
abstract: The allegations of insider trading against Representative Christopher Collins have revived calls for stricter rules about financial investments or corporate board seats held by members of Congress.
